instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.BUTTON_DISABLE: What is BUTTON_DISABLE? BUTTON_DISABLE disables the trackpad when SMC_LID is below 0.5v and the system believes the lid is closed. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Video internal or external, boots up and chimes, gpu heats up.
threads.message: I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, my customer spilled tea on it. At first it would not power on, I cleaned up the mobo, got it to power on, the customer brought it home, used it all night, closed the lid, which I am assuming placed it to sleep or suspend, the next day, the laptop would not power on, and the magsafe light would not come back on. I removed the board, cleaned it up again, and after lots of testing, the magsafe light worked, the computer powered on, everything seemed great, but here is where my problem started. I forgot the keyboard backlight cable underneath the motherboard when installing the motherboard back in, so I unscrewed a few screws (not all), propped up the board with a nylon spudger, this did flex the board a bit, I got the keyboard backlight cable out, but when I went to turn on the mac, to test everything out, I had no video on the display, and via HDMI and Mini-dispalyport, no video at all whatsoever. The computer does chime, you can hear it boot up, I have thermal imaging and it shows the GPU, CPU, and <CHIP>U1100</CHIP> all heating up. I already tried reflowing the <CHIP>U9650</CHIP>, but no luck. I may not be measuring things correctly so I am a bit of a novice when it comes to reading the schematics. I tried searching for any missing or broken components visually, but everything looks good visually. What should I do next? Thank you in advance. I am thinking this may have something to do with one of the S0-S5 components, but this is just an assumption because of the customer telling me she closed the lid. I also already tried a SMC and PRAM reset.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Video internal or external, boots up and chimes, gpu heats up.
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Inspect for corroded components on the areas affected by liquid spill.
Can be accumulated crap under CPU, GPU, or some VRAM chip.

Just in case, be sure <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is steady 3V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Video internal or external, boots up and chimes, gpu heats up.
threads.message:
Thank you! 
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is a steady 3.434. 
I do not have an ultrasonic cleaner, however the corrosion/liquid damage (I cleaned this up prior), I did find was over in two areas, <RESISTOR>R5250</RESISTOR> and surrounding area, then <CHIP>U4650</CHIP> and surrounding area.
CPU, GPU, and VRAM areas all look good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Video internal or external, boots up and chimes, gpu heats up.
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5250</RESISTOR> is right on <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> signal.
It should have 3V on both pins, when lid is open.
Should drop to 0V when lid is closed.
In case of broken trace, check <SIGNAL>BUTTON_DISABLE</SIGNAL> signal at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Video internal or external, boots up and chimes, gpu heats up.
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5250</RESISTOR> is 3.435.
The <SIGNAL>BUTTON_DISABLE</SIGNAL> on <TRANSISTOR>Q4801</TRANSISTOR> is also the same 3.435.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Video internal or external, boots up and chimes, gpu heats up.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BUTTON_DISABLE</SIGNAL> cannot have the same voltage!
You have broken trace somewhere...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Video internal or external, boots up and chimes, gpu heats up.
threads.message: I did not test all contact points on <TRANSISTOR>Q4801</TRANSISTOR>, but the <SIGNAL>BUTTON_DISABLE</SIGNAL> is 0 volts, and <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is 3.43 (all from <TRANSISTOR>Q4301</TRANSISTOR>). Still have a broken trace?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Video internal or external, boots up and chimes, gpu heats up.
threads.message:
0V looks good; you've said 3.435V on <SIGNAL>BUTTON_DISABLE</SIGNAL> before.
So <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> should be good all trace.
Inspect corroded area for bad resistors or crap between chip pins.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A No Video internal or external, boots up and chimes, gpu heats up.
threads.message: I found the issue, I looked where I had stuck my spudger more in detail, and I pulled away the protective black film covering the row of large capacitors, off to the side, <CAPACITOR>C9237</CAPACITOR> was the culprit. After I tested for continuity, found both sides were beeping. As I pulled the probes away, the capacitor disintegrated. So I replaced with a new capacitor, and tested on an external monitor, then tested the display, and both worked! Thank you so very much!!
